sourcesContent:
import React, { useEffect, useRef } from 'react'; import { Box, Container, Tabs, TabList, Tab, TabPanels, TabPanel, Heading, Text, Link, VStack, UnorderedList, ListItem, useColorModeValue, HStack, Select, } from '@chakra-ui/react'; const TabContent = () => { const mapRef = useRef(null); const bgColor = useColorModeValue('white', 'gray.800'); const borderColor = useColorModeValue('gray.200', 'gray.600'); const [selectedMetric, setSelectedMetric] = React.useState('AI Readiness Score'); // Function to get color based on value const getColor = (value, metric) => { if (!value) return '#cccccc'; // Default color for null values let normalizedValue; switch(metric) { case 'AI Readiness Score': normalizedValue = value / 89; // Max score is 89 break; case 'AI Investment (USD Millions)': normalizedValue = value / 328548; // Max investment break; case 'Population (Millions)': normalizedValue = value / 1441; // Max population break; default: normalizedValue = 0; } // Color gradient from red (low) to yellow (medium) to green (high) if (normalizedValue < 0.33) { return '#ff4444'; } else if (normalizedValue < 0.66) { return '#ffbb33'; } else { return '#00C851'; } }; useEffect(() => { const initializeMap = async () => { if (!mapRef.current || !window.L || !window.countryMapData) return; try { // Initialize map const map = window.L.map(mapRef.current, { center: [20, 0], zoom: 2, minZoom: 2, maxZoom: 10 }); // Add tile layer window.L.tileLayer('https://{s}.tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png', { attribution: 'Â© OpenStreetMap contributors' }).addTo(map); // Load GeoJSON data const response = await fetch('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/johan/world.geo.json/master/countries.geo.json'); const geoData = await response.json(); // Create the choropleth layer const geojsonLayer = window.L.geoJSON(geoData, { style: (feature) => { const countryData = window.countryMapData.find(c => c.ISO_A3 === feature.properties.iso_a3); return { fillColor: countryData ? getColor(countryData[selectedMetric], selectedMetric) : '#cccccc', weight: 1, opacity: 1, color: 'white', fillOpacity: 0.7 }; }, onEachFeature: (feature, layer) => { const countryData = window.countryMapData.find(c => c.ISO_A3 === feature.properties.iso_a3); if (countryData) { layer.bindPopup(` ${countryData.Country}
AI Readiness Score: ${countryData['AI Readiness Score']}
AI Investment: ${countryData['AI Investment (USD Millions)'] ? '$' + countryData['AI Investment (USD Millions)'].toLocaleString() + 'M' : 'N/A'}
Population: ${countryData['Population (Millions)']}M `); } } }).addTo(map); // Store map instance for cleanup mapRef.current._leaflet = map; mapRef.current._geojsonLayer = geojsonLayer; // Force a resize event setTimeout(() => { map.invalidateSize(); }, 100); } catch (error) { console.error('Error initializing map:', error); } }; if (window.L) { initializeMap(); } return () => { if (mapRef.current && mapRef.current._leaflet) { mapRef.current._leaflet.remove(); } }; }, [selectedMetric]); return ( Homepage Why Global Inclusion Matters Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming Enabling Participation Domain-Specific Governance Global Coordination Resources {/* Homepage Tab */} Inclusive Global AI Governance and Red Teaming Homepage AI's rapid advances are unevenly distributed across the world. Most AI development and investment are concentrated in a few countries (primarily in the Global North), yet its impacts will be felt globally, often by populations with little say in its design. This disconnect is stark: a PwC analysis estimates that by 2030, 84% of AI's economic gains will accrue to North America, Europe, and China, while only about 8% of the benefits reach all of Africa, Oceania and the rest of Asia combined. Global inequality is set to rise as countries leading in AI reap outsized rewards and those facing adoption barriers fall further behind. If AI governance remains non-inclusive, there is a risk that a few cultural and economic perspectives will dominate, imposing one-size-fits-all policies and values that may not suit local contexts. Without diverse voices, AI policies might overlook regional needs or ethical norms, and AI systems could carry hidden biases. For example, advanced language models already show geographic biases that favor high-income regions. Failing to involve Global South stakeholders in rule-making could mean Global North values and assumptions are baked into AI systems worldwide, to the detriment of other cultures. Inclusive global governance aims to correct this imbalance by engaging a broad coalition of nations and experts in shaping AI's future. {/* Why Global Inclusion Matters Tab */} Why Global Inclusion Matters Select Metric: Legend Low Medium High No Data Linguistic & Geographic Bias AI systems often perform poorly for languages or communities absent in training data. Independent researchers have found that large language models (trained mostly on English and European data) carry "geographic bias" â for instance, systematically underrating content related to African countries on subjective qualities like "intelligence" or "morality". Generative AI tools also struggle with many low-resource languages, leading to errors and exclusion of non-English speakers. These biases can amplify inequality (e.g. an AI assistant that works well in English but garbles Swahili is far less useful to African users). Health & Safety Risks If AI applications (like medical diagnosis tools) are developed using homogenous data, they can be dangerously unreliable for underrepresented groups. For example, an AI system for skin cancer screening was found to be less accurate on patients with darker skin, because most training images were of light-skinned individuals. Cultural Mismatches & Fairness AI systems often reflect the cultural context of their creators, which can cause problems when deployed globally. Generative AI models have been caught reinforcing stereotypes â for instance, a text-to-image generator trained on Western data might depict Indian festivals in an exotified, caricatured way. {/* Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming Tab */} Barriers to Inclusive Red Teaming Legal and Regulatory Barriers Many countries have unclear or restrictive laws around AI system testing. This creates legal uncertainty that discourages participation in red teaming efforts. Key issues include: Computer misuse and cybersecurity laws that may criminalize certain testing approaches Intellectual property restrictions limiting access to model details Data protection regulations affecting testing data collection and sharing Export controls on AI technologies that prevent cross-border collaboration Resource and Infrastructure Gaps Many regions face significant resource constraints that limit their ability to participate in AI development and testing: Limited access to computing infrastructure and high-performance hardware Insufficient funding for AI research and testing initiatives Lack of specialized training programs and educational resources Poor internet connectivity and digital infrastructure in some areas Knowledge and Expertise Barriers Technical expertise is often concentrated in a few global hubs, creating challenges for broader participation: Limited access to advanced AI training and education Language barriers in technical documentation and research Brain drain of AI talent to major tech hubs Lack of local mentorship and professional development opportunities {/* Enabling Participation Tab */} Enabling Participation Legal and Policy Solutions Creating an enabling environment for global participation requires addressing legal barriers through: Safe harbor provisions for legitimate AI testing activities Clear guidelines on permissible testing approaches International frameworks for cross-border collaboration Standardized protocols for responsible disclosure Capacity Building Initiatives Supporting the development of local expertise and infrastructure through: Regional AI research and testing centers Training programs and educational partnerships Funding for local AI safety initiatives Technical resource sharing programs Collaborative Networks Building networks to connect global participants: International research partnerships Mentorship programs connecting experts with emerging practitioners Knowledge sharing platforms and communities of practice Regular conferences and workshops focused on inclusive AI safety {/* Domain-Specific Governance Tab */} Domain-Specific Governance Healthcare AI Special considerations for AI systems in healthcare: Patient data privacy and protection requirements Medical device regulations and safety standards Cultural sensitivity in healthcare delivery Access and equity considerations Financial Services Governance frameworks for AI in financial applications: Fair lending and anti-discrimination requirements Risk management and system stability considerations Consumer protection measures Cross-border financial regulations Public Sector Applications Guidelines for government use of AI: Transparency and accountability requirements Public consultation processes Impact assessments for vulnerable populations Democratic oversight mechanisms {/* Global Coordination Tab */} Global Coordination International Frameworks Developing coordinated approaches to AI governance: Multilateral agreements on AI safety standards Shared principles for responsible AI development Cross-border incident response protocols International monitoring and enforcement mechanisms Regional Cooperation Building regional capacity and coordination: Regional AI safety centers and networks Shared research and testing infrastructure Harmonized regulatory approaches Joint capacity building initiatives Stakeholder Engagement Ensuring inclusive participation in governance: Multi-stakeholder dialogue processes Civil society participation mechanisms Industry-government partnerships Academic and research collaboration networks {/* Resources Tab */} Resources Global AI Governance Frameworks OECD AI Principles (2019) : Multilateral principles for Trustworthy AI, endorsed by 40+ countries. UNESCO Recommendation on AI Ethics (2021) : Landmark agreement by 193 countries. EU Artificial Intelligence Act : Comprehensive AI law with risk-based approach. Inclusive AI & Case Studies of Bias "Large Language Models are Geographically Biased" (Manvi et al. 2024): Research on LLM performance/bias across countries. Penn State/Univ. of Washington Study on Cultural Harm: Analysis of generative AI misrepresenting Indian contexts. Gender and Language Bias in AI Translation: e.g., Google Translate case study. Red Teaming, Safety, and Cybersecurity Analogies Knight Institute â "A Safe Harbor for AI Red Teaming" (Nov 2023) : Argues for legal protections. NIST AI Risk Management Framework 1.0 : Governance section provides guidelines. ); }; export default TabContent;
